channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: A Pocket Guide to the 2014 Kolkata Book Fair
item.description: The largest retail book fair, which begins Wednesday in West Bengal’s capital, also features the three-day Kolkata Language and Literary Festival.
item.dc:creator: By ANURADHA SHARMA

item.title: Islamist Party in Tunisia Hands Power to Caretaker Government
item.description: Ennahda, an Islamist party, ended two strife-ridden years as Tunisia’s first elected government, ceding power to a government of technocrats that will preside over elections this year.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: McCain Calls China a ‘Rising Threat’ in Baucus Confirmation Hearing
item.description: Max Baucus, who was nominated as the new United States ambassador to China, responded diplomatically to assertions that China represented a rising threat to the United States.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON
item.media:description: Senator Max Baucus is expected to win confirmation easily, as early as next week.

item.title: World Briefing: Bolivia: Flood Emergency Declared
item.description: The government declared a national emergency to deal with flooding that has claimed at least 30 lives and forced about 21,000 families from their homes over the past two months.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: Report of Possible Talks With North Korea to Thaw Ties
item.description: Japanese and North Korean officials may have held secret talks over the weekend in Vietnam, Kyodo News reported Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing: China: Chicken Sales Suspended Over Concerns About Avian Flu
item.description: As the Chinese get ready for Lunar New Year feasts, several areas in China have banned the sale of live chickens, as fears grew over the spread of avian influenza.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: World Briefing: Afghanistan: Literacy Effort Stalls
item.description: A program financed by the United States to bolster literacy rates among security forces has been plagued by weak oversight and accountability, according to a report by federal inspectors.
item.category: Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: U.N. to Visit Uranium Mine
item.description: The visit by United Nations inspectors is part of a temporary international agreement aimed at resolving the longstanding dispute over the Iranian nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Rebels in Syria Claim Control of Resources
item.description: The scramble for oil is turning what was once an essential source of income for Syria into a driving force in its civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD, CLIFFORD KRAUSS and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Violence has damaged pipelines and other energy infrastructure in Syria, leaving it dependent on imports from allies. Above, a tank at an oil refinery in Homs Province burned in November.

item.title: ‘Fragile Five’ Is the Latest Club of Emerging Nations in Turmoil
item.description: The name identifies Turkey, Brazil, India, South Africa and Indonesia as economies too dependent on skittish foreign investment to finance their growth ambitions.
item.dc:creator: By LANDON THOMAS Jr.

item.title: Sign of a Chill: E.U. Doesn’t Set Table for Putin
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia arrived in Brussels absent the customary ceremony, a small sign that unrest in Ukraine has chilled Russian relations with Europe.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Vladimir V. Putin at a news conference Tuesday with European Union officials in Brussels. Ukraine has been a source of tension.

item.title: Syrian Talks Disrupted by Congress’s Approval of Aid to Rebels
item.description: The Syrian government criticized Congress’s approval of support for the rebels, and the United Nations mediator decided not to continue talks in the afternoon.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: World Food Program officials say fighting in Homs has prevented humanitarian aid from reaching blockaded areas there.

item.title: Herat Journal: Afghan Justice Proves Complicated in Killing of 9-Year-Old Boy
item.description: The rule of law is a fragile concept in Afghanistan as shown in a case involving a prominent businessman, his friend on the court, and support from both the government and the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nasir Nowruzi, an Afghan businessman, says he now faces threats to his life after pursuing prosecution of the killers of his son.

item.title: After Crisis, Greeks Work to Promote ‘Social’ Economy
item.description: Businesses tired of dealing with bureaucrats and failing corporations are relying on volunteer networks to provide cheaper goods and to sell directly to customers.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Greek workers making soap and other cleaning products.

item.title: Lens Blog: Making Pictures, Finding Solutions in Nicaragua
item.description: Dismayed by the prevalence of kidney disease among Nicaraguan sugar cane workers, Ed Kashi is raising money to document the crisis and to spur dialogue.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: A grieving family said it was intimidated by the local police to accept $5,000 to keep quiet about the kidney disease-related death of a loved one.

item.title: Irish Government Ordered to Compensate Abuse Victim
item.description: A human rights court ruled that a woman should be compensated for the government’s failure to protect her from sexual abuse as a child at a state-funded Roman Catholic school in the 1970s.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Military Is Asked to Return Guantánamo Inmate to Yemen
item.description: A lawyer for Abdel Malik Ahmed Abdel Wahab al-Rahabi, a Guantánamo inmate for 12 years, sought his return to Yemen, but a military profile said there were risks.
item.category: Abdel Malik Ahmed Abdel Wahab al-Rahabi
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Merger Puts New Face on Opposition Election Bid in South Africa
item.description: The candidacy of Mamphela Ramphele represents a bold challenge to Jacob Zuma, whose African National Congress has dominated politics for 20 years.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.N. Takes New Steps in Central African Republic
item.description: The United Nations Security Council approved a resolution aimed at people suspected of committing war crimes in Central African Republic, upended by sectarian violence.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Egypt Locks Morsi in Soundproof Cage During Trial
item.description: The soundproof enclosure, unheard-of in Egyptian courts, showed the extraordinary measures that the new government is using to silence the deposed President Mohamed Morsi.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:credit: Egyptian State TV, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mohamed Morsi in a courtroom in Cairo on Tuesday, in an image from Egyptian State TV.

item.title: Pakistani University Cancels Event Promoting Teenager’s Memoir
item.description: Officials at Peshawar University said the provincial government of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa had forced them to cancel a ceremony honoring Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani education advocate.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Thai Aristocrat Joins Political Fray, Backing Elections
item.description: Malinee Chakrabandhu is a champion of elections at a time when many in Thailand’s upper classes are calling for the overthrow of the government and a suspension of democracy.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Paula Bronstein for The New York Times
item.media:description: Malinee Chakrabandhu is a self-described “black sheep” of her family.

item.title: The Lede: Video of Palestinian President is Shown at Tel Aviv Conference
item.description: President Mahmoud Abbas said that he could accept an Israeli military presence in the West Bank for a three-year transition period as part of a peace deal.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: The Lede: Egyptian Journalist Explains Hunger Strike in Prison Letter
item.description: An Egyptian journalist for Al Jazeera who was detained in August while covering the bloody crackdown on an Islamist sit-in in Cairo has embarked on a hunger strike, according to a letter from prison posted online by his family on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: The Lede: Scarlett Johansson’s Defense of SodaStream Factory in Occupied West Bank Fails to Sway Critics
item.description: In a statement released late Friday, the actress Scarlett Johansson rejected criticism of her new endorsement deal with SodaStream, which manufactures home carbonation systems in an Israeli settlement on occupied West Bank territory.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
